Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experiences in Plant Science at the Danforth Center
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU Site award to the Donald Danforth Plant Science Center, located in St. Louis, MO, will support the training of 10 students for 11 weeks during the summers of 2017- 2019. The program provides a comprehensive research experience in the areas of plant and life sciences. Students conduct a research project under the guidance of senior scientists at the Danforth Center, an independent non-profit private research institute dedicated to fundamental research in plant biology. This research component is supplemented with additional activities, including workshops in the Center's Integrated Microscopy, Proteomics & Mass Spectrometry, Phenotyping, Maker and Tissue Culture and Transformation facilities. Weekly meetings, a scientific retreat, field trips and a career panel will expose interns to current research topics in the plant sciences, provide exposure to several possible career paths and offer ample networking opportunities with Danforth Center scientists as well as those from other local institutions. Special emphasis will be on developing effective verbal and written communication skills. The program culminates in a one-day symposium where interns will deliver their projects via a scientific paper and presentation. Applications are available online and are due each February. The program runs each summer from May through August.

It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. The program aims to increase the diversity of the scientific field by offering extensive research experience and training to students from underrepresented groups and from rural areas. Since a goal of the Center's research is to have an impact on agricultural productivity and added value, the research conducted by interns has the potential to be of significant interest to the plant biology community and the community at large. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at national and international scientific conferences.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting http://www.danforthcenter.org/internship or by contacting internship@danforthcenter.org.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program at the Donald Danforth Plant Science Center (DDPSC) was funded for a three and one-half year period from 3/1/2017-8/31/2020 under federal award 1659812.  The Danforth Center is an independent non-profit private research institute dedicated to fundamental research in plant biology.  We trained 56 interns during the award period: 30 were funded directly from this grant and 26 were funded by other funding sources (primarily supplements to PI grants from other NSF funding).

 

Intellectual merit. As an NSF-REU site, we provided a well-rounded, comprehensive program for undergraduate students to obtain significant research experience in the areas of plant and life sciences. Students conducted research projects under the guidance and close mentorship of senior scientists. In addition to laboratory research, students prepared oral presentations and written reports summarizing their research projects. The research component was further supplemented with additional educational activities, including workshops in the Center’s Integrated Microscopy, Proteomics & Mass Spectrometry, Tissue Culture and Transformation, Bioinformatics and Phenotyping facilities.  Weekly meetings featured guest speakers covering topics that included guidance in written and oral reports, ethics in science, and current research conducted at the Danforth Center.  Tours and lectures at the plant research facilities of the Bio Research & Development Growth Park, Monsanto, Missouri Botanical Gardens, and Washington University provided exposure to several possible career paths in the plant sciences. Several events were organized to encourage interactions among interns and other scientists in various career stages at the Center.

 

Broader Impacts. Since a goal of the Center’s research is to have an impact on agricultural productivity, the research conducted by interns has the potential to be of significant interest to the plant biology community and the community at large.  The Danforth Center REU program helped prepare students for careers in the fields of plant biology and biotechnology.  In addition to the training they received in the lab, our interns interacted with scientists in academia, industries, biotech startups, field biologists, science communicators and patent attorneys. This gave interns an expanded view of the possible careers in science and provided a better understanding of how different disciplines interfaced to work towards solving the problems affecting our world.  Our program aimed to increase the diversity of the scientific field by offering extensive research experience and training to students from underrepresented groups, women, and students from smaller colleges that had limited research opportunities.  Of the interns funded directly by this grant, thirty-seven percent were from underrepresented groups, 70% were women, and 70% came from small schools.  The program activities were designed to fashion successful future scientists and entrepreneurs.  Currently, ninety-seven percent of these interns are working in STEM careers or pursing degrees in STEM.
